children.value: Flow in the ocean can be quantitatively described and forecast using a basic set of equations:
\nabla \cdot \mathbf{u} = \frac{\partial u}{\partial x} + \frac{\partial v}{\partial y} + \frac{\partial w}{\partial z}
children.html: ∇⋅u=∂u∂x+∂v∂y+∂w∂z\nabla \cdot \mathbf{u} = \frac{\partial u}{\partial x} + \frac{\partial v}{\partial y} + \frac{\partial w}{\partial z}∇⋅u=∂x∂u​+∂y∂v​+∂z∂w​
ρ=ρ(T,S,p)\rho = \rho(\mathrm{T}, \mathrm{S}, \mathrm{p})ρ=ρ(T,S,p)
∂TKE∂t=Production+Buoyancy+Transport−ε\frac{\partial{TKE}}{\partial t} = \mathrm{Production} + \mathrm{Buoyancy} + \mathrm{Transport} - \varepsilon∂t∂TKE​=Production+Buoyancy+Transport−ε

children.value: Here, we focus on understanding and observing the turbulent terms of the momentum equation and the TKE equation.
We have seen that the ocean is a turbulent system that exhibits a wide range of scales.
Solving for all scales is computationally not feasible.
as a framework to separate the mean and turbulent components of the flow, resulting in a tractable set of equations for large-scale ocean dynamics, and a turbulent part which can be parameterized.
Incompressuble Navier-Stokes equation under the Boussinesq approximation:

children.html: ∂u∂t⏟Storage of momentum+u⋅∇u⏟Advection of momentum=−1ρ0∇p⏟Pressure gradient force+bz^⏟Buoyancy force+f×u⏟Coriolis force+ν∇2u⏟Viscous dissipation,\underbrace{\frac{\partial\mathbf{u}}{\partial t}}_{\text{Storage of momentum}} + \underbrace{\mathbf{u} \cdot \nabla{\mathbf{u}}}_{\text{Advection of momentum}} = \underbrace{-\frac{1}{\rho_0}\nabla p}_{\text{Pressure gradient force}} + \underbrace{b \hat{z}}_{\text{Buoyancy force}} + \underbrace{f \times \mathbf{u}}_{\text{Coriolis force}} + \underbrace{\nu \nabla^2\mathbf{u}}_{\text{Viscous dissipation}},Storage of momentum∂t∂u​​​+Advection of momentumu⋅∇u​​=Pressure gradient force−ρ0​1​∇p​​+Buoyancy forcebz^​​+Coriolis forcef×u​​+Viscous dissipationν∇2u​​,
b=−gρ′ρ0b = -g \frac{\rho'}{\rho_0}b=−gρ0​ρ′​
fz^×uf \hat{z} \times \mathbf{u}fz^×u
f=2ωsin(ϕ)f = 2\omega sin(\phi)f=2ωsin(ϕ)

children.value: To separate the turbulent part from the mean part of the flow, we apply

children.alt: Reynolds decomposition splits the turbulent flow properties into a statistical mean and a statistically fluctuating part. Source: Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University

children.value: Reynolds decomposition splits the turbulent flow properties into a statistical mean and a statistically fluctuating part.
Reynolds decomposition separates the flow variables into a mean component and a fluctuating (turbulent) component:

children.html: u=u‾+u′\mathbf{u} = \overline{\mathbf{u}} + \mathbf{u'}u=u+u′
u‾ \overline{\mathbf{u}} u
u′ \mathbf{u'} u′

children.value: Similarly, the pressure field is decomposed as:

children.html: p=p‾+p′p = \overline{p} + p'p=p​+p′

children.value: The mean of the fluctuation is zero:

children.html: u′‾=0\overline{\mathbf{u'}} = 0u′=0

children.value: The mean of a product of a mean quantity and a fluctuating quantity is zero:

children.html: ab′‾=a‾b′‾=a‾⋅0=0\overline{a b'} = \overline{a} \overline{b'} = \overline{a} \cdot 0 = 0ab′=ab′=a⋅0=0
ba′‾=b‾a′‾=b‾⋅0=0\overline{b a'} = \overline{b} \overline{a'} = \overline{b} \cdot 0 = 0ba′=ba′=b⋅0=0

children.value: Recall the Navier-Stokes equation in the

children.html: ∂u∂t+u⋅∇u=−1ρ0∇p+bz^+ν∇2u.\frac{\partial\mathbf{u}}{\partial t} + \mathbf{u} \cdot \nabla \mathbf{u} = -\frac{1}{\rho_0} \nabla p + b \hat{z} % + f \times \mathbf{u} + \nu \nabla^2 \mathbf{u}.∂t∂u​+u⋅∇u=−ρ0​1​∇p+bz^+ν∇2u.
u=u‾+u′ \mathbf{u} = \overline{\mathbf{u}} + \mathbf{u'} u=u+u′
p=p‾+p′ p = \overline{p} + p' p=p​+p′

∂(u‾+u′)∂t⏟Storage of momentum+(u‾+u′)⋅∇(u‾+u′)⏟Advection of momentum=−1ρ0∇(p‾+p′)⏟Pressure gradient force+bz^⏟Buoyancy force+ν∇2(u‾+u′)⏟Viscous dissipation.\underbrace{\frac{\partial(\overline{\mathbf{u}} + \mathbf{u'})}{\partial t}}_{\text{Storage of momentum}} + \underbrace{(\overline{\mathbf{u}} + \mathbf{u'}) \cdot \nabla(\overline{\mathbf{u}} + \mathbf{u'})}_{\text{Advection of momentum}} = \underbrace{-\frac{1}{\rho_0}\nabla (\overline{p} + p')}_{\text{Pressure gradient force}} + \underbrace{b \hat{z}}_{\text{Buoyancy force}} % + \underbrace{f \times (\overline{\mathbf{u}} + \mathbf{u'})}_{\text{Coriolis force}} + \underbrace{\nu\nabla^2(\overline{\mathbf{u}} + \mathbf{u'})}_{\text{Viscous dissipation}}.Storage of momentum∂t∂(u+u′)​​​+Advection of momentum(u+u′)⋅∇(u+u′)​​=Pressure gradient force−ρ0​1​∇(p​+p′)​​+Buoyancy forcebz^​​+Viscous dissipationν∇2(u+u′)​​.

children.html: ∂u‾∂t‾+∂u′∂t‾+u‾⋅∇u‾‾+u‾⋅∇u′‾+u′⋅∇u‾‾+u′⋅∇u′‾=−1ρ0∇p‾‾−1ρ0∇p′‾+b‾z^+fz^×u′‾+ν∇2u‾‾+ν∇2u′‾\overline{\frac{\partial\overline{\mathbf{u}}}{\partial t}} +\cancel{\overline{\frac{\partial\mathbf{u'}}{\partial t}}} +\overline{\overline{\mathbf{u}} \cdot \nabla\overline{\mathbf{u}}} +\cancel{\overline{\overline{\mathbf{u}} \cdot \nabla\mathbf{u'}}} +\cancel{\overline{\mathbf{u'} \cdot \nabla\overline{\mathbf{u}}}} +\overline{\mathbf{u'} \cdot \nabla\mathbf{u'}} = -\overline{\frac{1}{\rho_0} \nabla \overline{p}} -\cancel{\overline{\frac{1}{\rho_0} \nabla p'}} + \overline{b} \hat{z} + \cancel{\overline{f \hat{z} \times \mathbf{u'}}} + \overline{\nu \nabla^2 \overline{\mathbf{u}}} + \cancel{\overline{\nu \nabla^2 \mathbf{u'}}}∂t∂u​​+∂t∂u′​​​+u⋅∇u+u⋅∇u′+u′⋅∇u+u′⋅∇u′=−ρ0​1​∇p​​−ρ0​1​∇p′​​+bz^+fz^×u′​​+ν∇2u+ν∇2u′

∂u‾∂t⏟Storage of momentum+u‾⋅∇u‾⏟Advection of mean momentum=−1ρ0∇p‾⏟Pressure gradient force+bz^⏟Buoyancy force+ν∇2u‾⏟Viscous dissipation−u′⋅∇u′‾⏟Turbulent momentum flux.\underbrace{\frac{\partial\overline{\mathbf{u}}}{\partial t}}_{\text{Storage of momentum}} + \underbrace{\overline{\mathbf{u}} \cdot \nabla\overline{\mathbf{u}}}_{\text{Advection of mean momentum}} = -\underbrace{\frac{1}{\rho_0}\nabla \overline{p}}_{\text{Pressure gradient force}} + \underbrace{b \hat{z}}_{\text{Buoyancy force}} \\ % + \underbrace{ f \hat{z} \times \overline{\mathbf{u}}}_{\text{Coriolis force}} + \underbrace{\nu \nabla^2 \overline{\mathbf{u}}}_{\text{Viscous dissipation}} - \underbrace{\overline{\mathbf{u'} \cdot \nabla\mathbf{u'}}}_{\text{Turbulent momentum flux}}.Storage of momentum∂t∂u​​​+Advection of mean momentumu⋅∇u​​=−Pressure gradient forceρ0​1​∇p​​​+Buoyancy forcebz^​​+Viscous dissipationν∇2u​​−Turbulent momentum fluxu′⋅∇u′​​.

children.value: , including Large Eddy Simulations (LES) and Reynolds-Averaged Navier-Stokes (RANS) models.
TKE is a direct measure of turbulence in a flow and is one of the most important variables in oceanography. The
provides insights into the physical processes generating and dissipating turbulence. It is directly related to the turbulent fluxes of momentum derived earlier.
Turbulent Kinetic Energy (TKE) per unit mass is defined as:

children.html: e=12ui′ui′‾.e = \frac{1}{2} \overline{u'_i u'_i}.e=21​ui′​ui′​​.

children.html: ui′ u'_i ui′​

children.value: and take the Reynolds average. After considerable manipulation the TKE equation for horizontally homogeneous flow emerges.

The following figure shows the steady state TKE budget for convective and stabilising cases in the ocean surface boundary layer.
